definitions.definition: To be the double of; to exceed by twofold; to contain or be worth twice as much as.
To increase by 100%, to become twice as large in size.
definitions.example: Our earnings have doubled in the last year.

definitions.definition: To get a two-base hit.
definitions.example: The batter doubled into the corner.

definitions.definition: (sometimes followed by up) To clench (a fist).
(often followed by together or up) To join or couple.
To repeat exactly; copy.
(often followed by as) To play a second part or serve a second role.
definitions.example: A spork is a kind of fork that doubles as a spoon.

definitions.definition: To turn sharply, following a winding course.
To sail around (a headland or other point).
To duplicate (a part) either in unison or at the octave above or below it.
(usually followed by "on") To be capable of performing (upon an additional instrument).
To make a call that will double certain scoring points if the preceding bid becomes the contract.
To double down.
To cause (a ball) to rebound from a cushion before entering the pocket.
(followed by for) To act as substitute.
To go or march at twice the normal speed.
To multiply the strength or effect of by two.
definitions.example: Sorry, this store does not double coupons.

definitions.definition: To unite, as ranks or files, so as to form one from each two.
(of a station) To transmit simultaneously on the same channel as another station, either unintentionally or deliberately, causing interference.
definitions.example: Could you please repeat your last transmission? Another station was doubling with you.

definitions.definition: Made up of two matching or complementary elements.
definitions.example: The closet has double doors.

definitions.definition: Of twice the quantity.
definitions.example: Give me a double serving of mashed potatoes.

definitions.definition: Of a family relationship, related on both the maternal and paternal sides of a family.
definitions.example: He's my double cousin as my mother's sister married my father's brother.

definitions.definition: Designed for two users.
definitions.example: a double room

definitions.definition: Folded in two; composed of two layers.
Stooping; bent over.
Having two aspects; ambiguous.
definitions.example: a double meaning

definitions.definition: False, deceitful, or hypocritical.
definitions.example: a double life

definitions.definition: Of flowers, having more than the normal number of petals.
Of an instrument, sounding an octave lower.
definitions.example: a double bass

definitions.definition: Of time, twice as fast.
Twice over; twofold; doubly.
Two together; two at a time. (especially in see double)
definitions.example: There are only a few beds, so some of the children will have to sleep double for the night.

definitions.definition: The double time, a marching cadence (pace) approaching running speed.
A projectile, usually of metal, shot from a gun at high speed.
An entire round of unfired ammunition for a firearm, including the projectile, the cartridge casing, the propellant charge, etc.
Ammunition for a sling or slingshot which has been manufactured for such use.
A printed symbol in the form of a solid circle, (•), often used in lieu of numbers for marking items in a list. (see also bulleted)
A large scheduled repayment of the principal of a loan; a balloon payment.
A rejection letter, as for employment, admission to a school or a competition.
definitions.example: John's not going to any of his top schools; he got a bullet from the last of them yesterday.

definitions.definition: One year of prison time
An ace (the playing card).
Anything that is projected extremely fast.
(in attributive use) Very fast (speedy).
definitions.example: bullet chess

definitions.definition: A plumb or sinker.
(particularly in Northern Ireland) The heavy projectile thrown in a game of road bowling.
A roughly bullet-shaped sweet consisting of a cylinder of liquorice covered in chocolate.
A small ball.
A cannonball.
The fetlock of a horse.
To draw attention to (text) by, or as if by, placing a graphic bullet in front of it.
To speed, like a bullet.
definitions.example: Their debut started slow, but bulleted to number six in its fourth week.

definitions.definition: To make a shot, especially with great speed.
definitions.example: He bulleted a header for his first score of the season.

definitions.definition: A young or little bull; a male calf.
(heading) To the greatest extent or degree; completely, entirely.
(heading) In a fully justified sense; truly, perfectly, actually.
To a moderate extent or degree; somewhat, rather.
Indicates agreement; "exactly so".
A series of passes made with the cape to distract the bull.
(authorship) The course of a story, comprising a series of incidents which are gradually unfolded, sometimes by unexpected means.
An area or land used for building on or planting on.
A graph or diagram drawn by hand or produced by a mechanical or electronic device.
A secret plan to achieve an end, the end or means usually being illegal or otherwise questionable.
definitions.example: The assassination of Lincoln was part of a larger plot.

definitions.definition: Contrivance; deep reach thought; ability to plot or intrigue.
Participation in any stratagem or conspiracy.
A plan; a purpose.
To conceive (a crime, etc).
definitions.example: They had plotted a robbery.

definitions.definition: To trace out (a graph or diagram).
definitions.example: They plotted the number of edits per day.

definitions.definition: To mark (a point on a graph, chart, etc).
definitions.example: Every five minutes they plotted their position.

definitions.definition: To conceive a crime, misdeed, etc.
definitions.example: They were plotting against the king.

definitions.definition: For the reason (that).
On account (of), for sake (of).
definitions.example: My life is ruined because of you!

definitions.definition: (by ellipsis) Used alone to refuse to provide a full answer a question begun with "why", usually taken as an anapodoton of the elided full phrase "Because I said so".
On account of, because of.
By or for the cause that; on this account that; for the reason that.
definitions.example: I hid myself because I was afraid.

definitions.definition: As is known, inferred, or determined from the fact that.
definitions.example: I don't think he is a nice person, because he yells at people for no reason.

definitions.definition: So that, in order that.
A person other than a family member, spouse or lover whose company one enjoys and towards whom one feels affection.
definitions.example: John and I have been friends ever since we were roommates at college.   Trust is important between friends.   I used to find it hard to make friends when I was shy.

definitions.definition: An associate who provides assistance.
definitions.example: The Automobile Association is every motorist's friend.   The police is every law-abiding citizen's friend.

definitions.definition: A person with whom one is vaguely or indirectly acquainted.
definitions.example: a friend of a friend;  I added him as a friend on Facebook, but I hardly know him.

definitions.definition: A person who backs or supports something.
definitions.example: I’m not a friend of cheap wine.

definitions.definition: An object or idea that can be used for good.
definitions.example: Wiktionary is your friend.

definitions.definition: (used only in the vocative) Used as a form of address when warning someone.
definitions.example: You’d better watch it, friend.

definitions.definition: A function or class granted special access to the private and protected members of another class.
A spring-loaded camming device.
A lover; a boyfriend or girlfriend.
A relative, a relation by blood or marriage.
definitions.example: Friends agree best at a distance.

definitions.definition: To act as a friend to, to befriend; to be friendly to, to help.
To add (a person) to a list of friends on a social networking site; to officially designate (someone) as a friend.
To give (especially public) notice of (something); to announce publicly.
To provide information about a person or goods and services to influence others.
definitions.example: For personal needs, advertise on the internet or in a local newspaper.

definitions.definition: To provide public information about (a product, service etc.) in order to attract public awareness and increase sales.
definitions.example: Over the air, they advertise their product on drive-time radio talk shows and TV news shows.

definitions.definition: To notify (someone) of something; to call someone's attention to something.
In gin rummy, to discard a card of one's preferred suit so as to mislead the opponent into thinking you do not want it.
A single act of visiting.
A meeting with a doctor at their surgery or the doctor's at one's home.
To habitually go to (someone in distress, sickness etc.) to comfort them. (Now generally merged into later senses, below.)
To go and meet (a person) as an act of friendliness or sociability.
Of God: to appear to (someone) to comfort, bless, or chastise or punish them. (Now generally merged into later senses, below.)
To punish, to inflict harm upon (someone or something).
Of a sickness, misfortune etc.: to afflict (someone).
To inflict punishment, vengeance for (an offense) on or upon someone.
To go to (a shrine, temple etc.) for worship. (Now generally merged into later senses, below.)
To go to (a place) for pleasure, on an errand, etc.
To lay or place; to put (one thing to another)
definitions.example: to apply cream to a rash

definitions.definition: To put to use; to use or employ for a particular purpose, or in a particular case
definitions.example: to apply funds to the repayment of a debt

definitions.definition: To make use of, declare, or pronounce, as suitable, fitting, or relative
definitions.example: We need to apply the skills we've learned to solve this problem

definitions.definition: To put closely; to join; to engage and employ diligently, or with attention
To to address; to refer; generally used reflexively.
To submit oneself as a candidate (with the adposition "to" designating the recipient of the submission, and the adposition "for" designating the position).
definitions.example: I recently applied to the tavern for a job as a bartender.

definitions.definition: To pertain or be relevant to a specified individual or group.
definitions.example: That rule only applies to foreigners.

definitions.definition: To busy; to keep at work; to ply.
To visit.
Resembling apples, apple-like.
Of, or pertaining to, apples.
A small piece broken from a larger piece of solid material.
A damaged area of a surface where a small piece has been broken off.
definitions.example: This cup has a chip in it.

definitions.definition: (games) A token used in place of cash.
A sovereign (the coin).
A circuit fabricated in one piece on a small, thin substrate.
A hybrid device mounted in a substrate, containing electronic circuitry and miniaturised mechanical, chemical and/or biochemical devices.
(especially in the plural) A fried strip of potato of square or rectangular cross-section; a french fry.
definitions.example: Do you want sauce or mayonnaise on your chips?

definitions.definition: (especially in the plural) A thin, crisp, fried slice of potato, or sometimes another vegetable; a crisp.
A shot during which the ball travels more predominantly upwards than in a regular shot, as to clear an obstacle.
A takeout that hits a rock at an angle.
A dried piece of dung, often used as fuel.
(northern) A receptacle, usually for strawberries or other fruit.
A small, near-conical piece of food added in baking.
A small rectangle of colour printed on coated paper for colour selection and matching. A virtual equivalent in software applications.
The triangular piece of wood attached to the log line.
Wood or Cuban palm leaf split into slips, or straw plaited in a special manner, for making hats or bonnets.
Anything dried up, withered, or without flavour.
A low shot that travels further along the ground than it does in the air.
To chop or cut into small pieces.
definitions.example: The workers chipped the dead branches into mulch.

definitions.definition: To break small pieces from.
definitions.example: Be careful not to chip the paint.

definitions.definition: To play a shot hitting the ball predominantly upwards rather than forwards. In association football specifically, when the shot is a shot on goal, the opposing goalkeeper may be the direct object of the verb, rather than the ball.
To upgrade an engine management system, usually to increase power.
To become chipped.
definitions.example: This varnish chips easily.

definitions.definition: (often with "in") To ante (up).
To fit (an animal) with a microchip.
(often with "in") to contribute.
definitions.example: Everyone needs to chip in £1 for George's leaving collection

definitions.definition: (also, to chip at) To make fun of.
Furniture with a top surface to accommodate a variety of uses.
A two-dimensional presentation of data.
The top of a stringed instrument, particularly a member of the violin family: the side of the instrument against which the strings vibrate.
One half of a backgammon board, which is divided into the inner and outer table.
The flat topmost facet of a cut diamond.
To tabulate; to put into a table or grid.
definitions.example: to table fines

definitions.definition: To supply (a guest, client etc.) with food at a table; to feed.
To delineate; to represent, as in a picture; to depict.
(non-US) To put on the table of a commission or legislative assembly; to propose for formal discussion or consideration, to put on the agenda.
To remove from the agenda, to postpone dealing with; to shelve (to indefinitely postpone consideration or discussion of something).
definitions.example: The legislature tabled the amendment, so they will not be discussing it until later.

definitions.definition: To join (pieces of timber) together using coaks.
To put on a table.
To make board hems in the skirts and bottoms of (sails) in order to strengthen them in the part attached to the bolt-rope.
To bring (a system, etc.) online; to promote to an active or running state.
Of a system: connected (generally electrically) to a larger network.
Available over, or delivered from, the Internet.
definitions.example: I prefer to read online newspapers.

definitions.definition: Connected to the Internet.
definitions.example: I'll be online tonight, so I'll be able to reply to your email.

definitions.definition: Available on a computer system, even if not networked.
definitions.example: Press the F1 key to access the online help.

definitions.definition: Of a system: active, particularly building facilities (such as power) or a factory or power plant.
definitions.example: Once this factory comes online, it will double car production in our country!

definitions.definition: While online; while in a running or active state, or connected to the Internet.
definitions.example: He works online.

definitions.definition: Refuse, waste, garbage, junk, trash.
definitions.example: The rubbish is collected every Thursday in Gloucester, but on Wednesdays in Cheltenham.

definitions.definition: (by extension) An item, or items, of low quality.
definitions.example: Much of what they sell is rubbish.

definitions.definition: (by extension) Nonsense.
definitions.example: Everything the teacher said during that lesson was rubbish. How can she possibly think that a bass viol and a cello are the same thing?

definitions.definition: Debris or ruins of buildings.
To criticize, to denigrate, to denounce, to disparage.
Exceedingly bad; awful.
definitions.example: This has been a rubbish day, and it’s about to get worse: my mother-in-law is coming to stay.

definitions.definition: Used to express that something is exceedingly bad, awful, or terrible.
definitions.example:
The one day I actually practice my violin, the teacher cancels the lesson.
Aw, rubbish! Though at least this means you have time to play football.

definitions.definition: Used to express that what was recently said is nonsense or untrue; balderdash!, nonsense!
definitions.example: Rubbish! I did nothing of the sort!

definitions.definition: A person who is qualified or professionally engaged in any branch of engineering.
A title given to an engineer.
A person who controls motion of substance (such as a locomotive).
A person employed in the engine room of a ship.
To design, construct or manage something as an engineer.
To alter or construct something by means of genetic engineering.
To plan or achieve some goal by contrivance or guile; to wangle or finagle.
To control motion of substance; to change motion.
To work as an engineer.
An act of lifting or raising.
The act of transporting someone in a vehicle; a ride; a trip.
definitions.example: He gave me a lift to the bus station.

definitions.definition: Mechanical device for vertically transporting goods or people between floors in a building; an elevator.
definitions.example: Take the lift to the fourth floor.

definitions.definition: An upward force, such as the force that keeps aircraft aloft.
(measurement) The difference in elevation between the upper pool and lower pool of a waterway, separated by lock.
A thief.
The lifting of a dance partner into the air.
Permanent construction with a built-in platform that is lifted vertically.
An improvement in mood.
The amount or weight to be lifted.
definitions.example: What's the maximum lift of this crane?

definitions.definition: The space or distance through which anything is lifted.
A rise; a degree of elevation.
definitions.example: the lift of a lock in canals

definitions.definition: A liftgate.
A rope leading from the masthead to the extremity of a yard below, and used for raising or supporting the end of the yard.
One of the steps of a cone pulley.
(shoemaking) A layer of leather in the heel of a shoe.
That portion of the vibration of a balance during which the impulse is given.
To raise or rise.
definitions.example: The fog eventually lifted, leaving the streets clear.

definitions.definition: To steal.
To source directly without acknowledgement; to plagiarise.
To arrest (a person).
To remove (a ban, restriction, etc.).
To alleviate, to lighten (pressure, tension, stress, etc.)
To cause to move upwards.
To lift weights; to weight-lift.
definitions.example: She lifts twice a week at the gym.

definitions.definition: To try to raise something; to exert the strength for raising or bearing.
To elevate or improve in rank, condition, etc.; often with up.
To bear; to support.
To collect, as moneys due; to raise.
To transform (a function) into a corresponding function in a different context.
To buy a security or other asset previously offered for sale.
Air.
The sky; the heavens; firmament; atmosphere.
The beginning of an activity.
definitions.example: The movie was entertaining from start to finish.

definitions.definition: A sudden involuntary movement.
definitions.example: He woke with a start.

definitions.definition: The beginning point of a race, a board game, etc.
definitions.example: Captured pieces are returned to the start of the board.

definitions.definition: An appearance in a sports game, horserace, etc., from the beginning of the event.
definitions.example: Jones has been a substitute before, but made his first start for the team last Sunday.

definitions.definition: A young plant germinated in a pot to be transplanted later.
An initial advantage over somebody else; a head start.
definitions.example: to get, or have, the start

definitions.definition: To begin, commence, initiate.
To begin an activity.
definitions.example: The rain started at 9:00.

definitions.definition: To have its origin (at), begin.
definitions.example: The blue line starts one foot away from the wall.

definitions.definition: To startle or be startled; to move or be moved suddenly.
To break away, to come loose.
To put into play.
To pour out; to empty; to tap and begin drawing from.
definitions.example: to start a water cask

definitions.definition: To start one's periods (menstruation).
definitions.example: Have you started yet?

definitions.definition: A tail, or anything projecting like a tail.
A handle, especially that of a plough.
The curved or inclined front and bottom of a water wheel bucket.
The arm, or level, of a gin, drawn around by a horse.
A thin, slippery mix of clay and water.
Mud, slime.
A twig or shoot; a cutting.
A descendant, a scion.
A young person (now usually with of introducing descriptive qualifier).
definitions.example: She couldn't hurt a fly, young slip of a girl that she is.

definitions.definition: A long, thin piece of something.
A small piece of paper, especially one longer than it is wide, typically a form for writing on or one giving printed information.
definitions.example: a salary slip

definitions.definition: (marine insurance) A memorandum of the particulars of a risk for which a policy is to be executed. It usually bears the broker's name and is initiated by the underwriters.
An act or instance of slipping.
definitions.example: I had a slip on the ice and bruised my hip.

definitions.definition: A woman's undergarment worn under a skirt or dress to conceal unwanted nudity that may otherwise be revealed by the skirt or dress itself; a shift.
A slipdress.
A mistake or error.
A berth; a space for a ship to moor.
A difference between the theoretical distance traveled per revolution of the propeller and the actual advance of the vessel.
A slipway.
A one-time return to previous maladaptive behaviour after cure.

Any of several fielding positions to the off side of the wicket keeper, designed to catch the ball after being deflected from the bat; a fielder in that position (See first slip, second slip, third slip, fourth slip and fifth slip.)
A number between 0 and 1 that is the difference between the angular speed of a rotating magnetic field and the angular speed of its rotor, divided by the angular speed of the magnetic field.
A leash or string by which a dog is held; so called from its being made in such a manner as to slip, or become loose, by relaxation of the hand.
An escape; a secret or unexpected desertion.
definitions.example: He gave the warden the slip and escaped from the prison.

definitions.definition: A portion of the columns of a newspaper etc. struck off by itself; a proof from a column of type when set up and in the galley.
A child's pinafore.
An outside covering or case.
definitions.example: a pillow slip

definitions.definition: A counterfeit piece of money, made from brass covered with silver.
Matter found in troughs of grindstones after the grinding of edge tools.
An aqueous suspension of minerals, usually clay, used, among other things, to stick workpieces together.
A particular quantity of yarn.
A narrow passage between buildings.
A long seat or narrow pew in churches, often without a door.
A dislocation of a lead, destroying continuity.

The motion of the centre of resistance of the float of a paddle wheel, or the blade of an oar, through the water horizontally, or the difference between a vessel's actual speed and the speed it would have if the propelling instrument acted upon a solid; also, the velocity, relatively to still water, of the backward current of water produced by the propeller.
The difference between the actual and synchronous speeds of an induction motor.
A fish, the sole.
To lose one’s traction on a slippery surface; to slide due to a lack of friction.
To err.
To accidentally reveal a secret or otherwise say something unintentional.
To move or fly (out of place); to shoot; often with out, off, etc.
definitions.example: A bone may slip out of place.

definitions.definition: To pass (a note, money, etc.), often covertly.
definitions.example: She thanked the porter and slipped a ten-dollar bill into his hand.

definitions.definition: To cause to move smoothly and quickly; to slide; to convey gently or secretly.
To move quickly and often secretively; to depart, withdraw, enter, appear, intrude, or escape as if by sliding.
definitions.example: Some errors slipped into the appendix.

definitions.definition: To move down; to slide.
definitions.example: Profits have slipped over the past six months.

definitions.definition: To release (a dog, a bird of prey, etc.) to go after a quarry.
To remove the skin of a soft fruit, such as a tomato or peach, by blanching briefly in boiling water, then transferring to cold water so that the skin peels, or slips, off easily.
To omit; to lose by negligence.
To cut slips from; to cut; to take off; to make a slip or slips of.
definitions.example: to slip a piece of cloth or paper

definitions.definition: To cause to slip or slide off, or out of place.
definitions.example: A horse slips his bridle; a dog slips his collar.

definitions.definition: To bring forth (young) prematurely; to slink.
To cause (a schedule or release, etc.) to go, or let it go, beyond the allotted deadline.
The first meal of the day, usually eaten in the morning.
definitions.example: You should put more protein in her breakfast so she will grow.

definitions.definition: (by extension) A meal consisting of food normally eaten in the morning, which may typically include eggs, sausages, toast, bacon, etc.
definitions.example: We serve breakfast all day.

definitions.definition: The celebratory meal served after a wedding (and occasionally after other solemnities e.g. a funeral).
(largely obsolete outside religion) A meal eaten after a period of (now often religious) fasting.
To eat the morning meal.
To serve breakfast to.
